block.p: Companies

Another sacred cow at I.B.M. is endangered: the corporate headquarters. In a sign of its new cost-cutting ways, the company is considering vacating its head office in Armonk, N.Y. [ Page A1. ] A move by I.B.M. from Armonk would be another blow to the Westchester County economy. [ D3. ]
Companies

Another sacred cow at I.B.M. is endangered: the corporate headquarters. In a sign of its new cost-cutting ways, the company is considering vacating its head office in Armonk, N.Y. [ Page A1. ] A move by I.B.M. from Armonk would be another blow to the Westchester County economy. [ D3. ]
New York insurance regulators are said to be investigating the Prudential Insurance Company in the sale of financial products that had not been approved by the state. [ D1. ]
The board of Paramount Communications recommended that Paramount shareholders accept the tender offer by QVC Network and reject Viacom's latest offer. [ D1. ]
The head of a movie studio financed by JVC resigned. The souring of the four-year relationship raises questions about the commitment of Japanese investors to Hollywood. [ D4. ]
Vons Companies, the largest supermarket operator in Southern California, made good on a pledge, opening the first of 12 new stores in low-income neighborhoods in the Los Angeles area. [ D4. ]
Tandy Corporation plans to open 30 Computer City and Incredible Universe computer and electronics superstores this year. [ D4. ]
Digital Equipment and USA Video Corporation will team up on a commercial market test of video-on-demand services. [ D4. ]
American Express introduced its first new plastic card in seven years -- a corporate purchasing card. [ D4. ]
The Los Angeles Times and Pacific Telesis have joined forces to offer an electronic shopping information service. [ D5. ] The Economy
Producer prices fell one-tenth of a percent in December, showing inflation under control. But much of the good news on inflation came on a 3.5 percent drop in the price of energy. [ D1. ]

Some 150 American Indian tribes have entered or plan to enter the gaming business. But for many tribes, there are growing tensions over who -- the tribes or the gaming companies -- will reap the profits. [ D1. ]
The Supreme Court reacted skeptically to the Clinton Administration's defense of the 1992 act regulating cable television. [ A12. ] International

Kazakhstan, a former Soviet republic, has made agreements with a group of seven oil companies that could allow exploratory drilling in the North Caspian Sea, an area where drilling has been banned since it was declared a nature preserve in the 1970's. [ D2. ]
French companies will aqain be allowed access to China's market as a result of a commitment by the French Government to ban further arm sales to Taiwan. [ A11. ] Markets
Blue-chip stocks retreated as investors again took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.68 points, to 3,848.63. [ D8. ]
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose on buying prompted by the report on producer prices. [ D16. ]
The inflation report was bad news for the dollar, which weakened against most major currencies. [ D19. ]
Crude oil prices plunged amid speculation that a Germany company might liquidate up to $865 million in contracts. [ D19. ] Today's Columns
A new campaign for Diet Coke, the leading diet soft drink, departs from the old, bland advertising strategies once characteristic of Coca-Cola. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D1. ]

A proposal for Government-owned corporation to manage the inefficient air traffic control system makes sense, but the plan faces many obstacles. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] It's not for the faint of heart, but investing in the debt owed to Western commercial banks by the former Soviet Union is a good bet, some traders say. Market Place. [ D8. ]
